snippet: As sporadic fighting has become continual across the nation, the International Committee of the Red Cross said that the conflict can be considered a civil war.
abstract: International Committee of the Red Cross says conflict in Syria can now be considered a civil war, as sporadic fighting becomes continual across the nation; Syrian government denies it used heavy weapons to attack a small farming community, although United Nations monitors documented substantial destruction in the village; attack left scores dead and drew sharp international condemnation.

byline.contributor: Dalal Mawad contributed reporting from Beirut, Hwaida Saad from Antakya, Turkey, and an employee of The New York Times from Damascus, Syria.

lead_paragraph: As sporadic fighting has become continual across the nation, the International Committee of the Red Cross said that the conflict can be considered a civil war.
